docs.lead_paragraph: THIS is what Debbie Karamanol remembers about her 12-year marriage: Her husband threw hot coffee on her. He broke her hand. He blackened her eyes and blackened her eyes and blackened her eyes. He threw her down the stairs for cooking pork chops too rare. He threw her down the stairs for carrying the baby he wanted aborted. This is what she knows about her life after marriage: She runs her own business. It grossed $357,000 last year, and she expects to double that this year. She hires women like her, women whose husbands once beat them and who have mustered the courage to leave that life to make it on their own. It is a source of support -- financial and emotional -- for herself, her business partner, Pam Sullivan, and her 12 sales representatives, all who have left abusive husbands.
docs.abstract: Debbie Karamanol left abusive husband and runs her own business in Hoboken, NJ; company, Independent Graphics, is printing brokerage; it is source of support--financial and emotional--for Karamanol, her business partner, Pam Sullivan, and her 12 sales representatives, all of whom have left abusive husbands; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: AFTER 10 months of campaigning, after the expenditure of hundreds of millions of dollars, after innumerable witless speeches and enough wretched television commercials to last a lifetime or two, the voters of America are underwhelmed, or so they tell the pollsters. Many of them say it doesn't really matter who is elected President this week. They are wrong.

headline.main: Where the Choice (Yes, a Choice) Lies on Tuesday

docs.abstract: Major differences in policies likely to be followed by Pres Clinton or Bob Dole if they win Presidential election discussed (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: TELEX COMMUNICATION GROUP, Minneapolis, a maker of audio, wireless and multimedia communications devices for the commercial and industrial markets, hired the investment banking firm Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, to study options that include the sale of all or part of the company, a possible public stock offering or recapitalization. PIONEER FINANCIAL SERVICES, Schaumburg, Ill., which sells health insurance, life insurance and annuities, has sold its managed health care unit, National Health Services Inc., to United Payors and United Providers Inc. for cash and warrants. PHILIP ENVIRONMENTAL INC., Hamilton, Ontario, an industrial services concern, said its Philip Utilities Management Corp. unit bought Uniflo Utilities Management Corp., Hamilton, Ontario, a pipeline repair company, for an undisclosed amount.
docs.abstract: Telex Communication Group hires Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette to study options, including possible sale of company or public stock offering (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: For hundreds of years the leaders of this wild and blustery land donned their fighting tartans and sought their independence from England with swords and truncheons and longbows and muskets. Today the cry for Scottish independence is raised by a former oil analyst for the Royal Bank of Scotland who wears a navy blue pinstriped suit and a red boardroom tie. His choice of weapon is the calculator.
docs.abstract: Alex Salmond, head of Scottish Nationalist Party and member of British Parliament, wants England to grant Scotland its independence; photo (M)
